2775: Arena of the Ancients.author: BobbySinclair
2775: Arena of the Ancients.text_parsed:
Wow, the people complaining about this card have obviously never played EDH. For 3 mana, you can instantly douse any Voltron deck, or where commanders need to tap to use abilities, and at the very least, hamper any EDH deck's plans. Krenko, Mob Boss? Heartless Hidetsugu? Jaya Ballard, Task Mage? Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker? Niv-Mizzet, the Firemind? Marrow-Gnawer? Visara the Dreadful? Zirilan of the Claw? Need I share more generals that you can completely douse?

Take general damage winning out of the question. Put it in a lifegain deck, and your opponent has got to mill you. Then chuck in a Elixir of immortality and laugh in their face. Don't forget to chuck in a Darksteel Forge to keep your Arena around, mind you. Then they've got to exile it.

And what about your own general? It's an artifact, so it'll fit in any deck. Tap your opponent's generals, then play your own. If they're not affected by tapping, all the better! Geth, Lord of the Vault, Grimgrin, Corpse-Born, Memnarch, Oona, Queen of the Fae, Sliver Queen, Zedruu the Greathearted. All these generals either aren't affected by tapping, or can easily be untapped.

And what abut some combos? Quest for Renewal? Leyline of Singularity? Urabrask the Hidden? Amulet of Vigor? Honestly, if you're still calling this card bad, and don't think that keeping your opponent's legendaries tapped for THREE COLOURLESS is one of the most OP abilities EVER, then you don't know how to play Magic.

2776: Ashnod's Altar.author: PEGU
2776: Ashnod's Altar.text_parsed:
@endersblade: It is not common. It is uncommon. The card is from Antiquities set and they did not have that golden and silver rarity markings back in the days...

What comes in the card itself... I just love it. It makes good use to early game creatures you can use later to get big hitters earlyer to game. Since the activation is free, you can also use it to sacrafice the target before your opponent gets something extra by targeting your creature (like life points). It also negates lifelink creatures from sucking the fun out of your small blockers or attackers.

Never underestimate the power of extra mana or the power to dictate when your creatures die.

4,5/5

2786: Jeweled Bird.author: Qoios-Mauryn
2786: Jeweled Bird.text_parsed:
@SlackWareWolf:
{sarcastictrollrant}
Congratulations!

You are right, and all those people who don't play this game for ante are sissies who just aren't Man enough to play this game the way it was played eighteen years ago. It can't just be that they simply enjoy other methods of play, depending on the situation (possibly including Ante, when consented to by all players), because there is only one right way to play the game, and that's your way. And only wusses would ever mulligan, or let an opponent mulligan, because the only acceptable way to play this game of strategy is to gamble on the games, and then allow chance to skew the results to an irrecoverable degree. Anyone who has any opinion other than this single view is clearly inferior.

While we're at it, lets do away with those silly ban lists, restricted lists, the increased minimum deck size, and most certainly that four-copies-per-card limit. Constructed deck restrictions aren't what Magic is about, after all, and that surely holds true even with modern cards, because the game hasn't massively changed over the years at all, right? If my opponent can't beat my deck of 40 copies of Chancellor of the Dross, then they deserve to lose on turn zero and lose a card permanently, to boot.

And what's with all these different formats, and card rotating out, huh? Eighteen years ago, no cards had rotated out, and that's the way this game should stay forever, no exceptions. All cards ever printed should be usable in all contexts, and there should never be divergent rules systems that must be balanced in distinct ways, often by disallowing certain cards or altering fundamental rules of the game. The only thing that these different formats do is give new players the impression that there are numerous acceptable ways to play this game, all of which can be enjoyable in different ways, for different reasons. We don't want them getting that wrong idea stuck in their heads. Then they might even commit that most atrocious crime of failing to be informed on an outmoded rule referenced by very few cards, and done away with in the earliest days of this game, from before when many of the newest generation of players could form whole sentences.

Good job, you've successfully changed the mind of a random stranger on the internet by ranting about their inferiority due to having tastes that differ from yours, and now that person is just as closed-minded and bigoted over a card game as you are. Don't you feel oh so very satisfied?
{/sarcastictrollrant}

Your true friend and convert,
Summer Glau

2788: Obelisk of Undoing.author: Japicx
2788: Obelisk of Undoing.text_parsed:
Sorry, MechaKraken, but the way the rules work, permanents exist only on the battlefield. A planeswalker card in a graveyard is a permanent card, but not a permanent, so you can't use Obelisk of Undoing to put it back into your hand. It can't bring back exiled cards, either.

Obelisk of Undoing is just an extremely weak and awkward card. There are many, many cards that can do the same job far more efficiently.

2788: Obelisk of Undoing.author: Adromalath
2788: Obelisk of Undoing.text_parsed:
This card is extremely bad, I know, but it still holds a special place in my heart for being the card that first got my girlfriend to "get" the stack when I taught her how to play.

She had just learned the basics of the game and I had tried to explain the stack to her but she didn't understand why it was useful. Then a day later she was looking through a bunch crap rares I had lying around and saw this. She looked at it and said "Wow, this is terri...well, it can save my guys from dying, right?"

So, of all the cards in Magic, THIS is the one that made her understand one of the most fundamental things about the game.

2788: Obelisk of Undoing.author: ZaisConsultant
2788: Obelisk of Undoing.text_parsed:
I know this card isn't the greatest, but it isn't garbage.
It's a reusable way to- at instant speed- get your stuff back to your hand. If someone tries to kill a permanent of yours, return it. If a permanent you have is about to be stolen, return it.
You can also use this to return Plainswalkers who are about to die, or other permanents that are almost or completely out of counters like Iceberg or Parallax Wave. Or permanents that have to many counters like Voodoo Doll.
A specific combo I can think of is to use this with Delaying Shield to save your life.
This card DOES have uses, and i can actually see it appearing in some decks.
It definately not as bad as, say, Wood Elemental

2790: Runesword.author: longwinded
2790: Runesword.text_parsed:
@achilles
Some proto-equipment uses the falls away method, some doesn't (like Tawnos's Weaponry). I think the earliest use was Sandals of Abdallah, and in flavor terms it makes a lot of sense for them to disappear: they let you walk on water, and if you die while doing so, you and they both sink. Similarly, Flying Carpet was lost in the user's fatal plummet, until Classic Sixth Edition when they tried to fix the card by removing that stipulation. (Sixth is the only set I know of to deliberately change card text to make cards better than originally intended.)

@Ava
When a white knight dies, you don't get to keep the horse and armor for someone else. Pretty much every creature brings all the necessary equipment it can use, and it's lost when they fall (and still with them if they get resurrected). Equipment actually says something about the much glossed-over qualities of time and distance in a round of magic. Is a player's turn a minute? a wave of an attack? A skirmish in a long battle? A battle of a small war? There are cards to support any of those interpretations. At the same time, how small is the battlefield? Implicit in equip rules is the assumption that the battlefield is small enough and time between turns long enough that you can pick up equipment from wherever your friend fell and use it for yourself. (But then again, also implicit is the notion that a Craw Wurm can wear a pair of Trailblazer's Boots, so it's not something anyone should spend too much time worrying about.)

2801: Dance of Many.author: Doom_Pie
2801: Dance of Many.text_parsed:
I put one of these in my Zur the Enchanter EDH deck and it has been used to great effect. Sure most of the time I go for stuff like Oblivion Ring with Zur instead, but this can either straight up kill an opponent's General, or copy any other useful creature on the field. And since you're getting most of your stuff with Zur's ability, the isn't terribly hard to pay if you chose to copy something non-legendary.

My only wish for this card is that it functioned more like other cards with the "Clone" effect where it doesn't target the creature it's copying. That way I could have an easy way around all those blasted Lightning Greaves getting equipped to Generals in EDH.
2801: Dance of Many.text_posted:
I put one of these in my [autocard]Zur the Enchanter[/autocard] EDH deck and it has been used to great effect. And since you're getting most of your stuff with Zur's ability, the [UU] isn't terribly hard to pay if you chose to copy something non-legendary.

My only wish for this card is that it functioned more like other cards with the "[autocard]Clone[/autocard]" effect where it doesn't target the creature it's copying. That way I could have an easy way around all those blasted [autocard]Lightning Greaves[/autocard] getting equipped to Generals in EDH.

2802: Dandân.author: stygimoloch
2802: Dandân.text_parsed: When is four power for two mana bad? When it's Dandan. It falls into the trap that many cards in the early days fell into: if you're going to jump through hoops, you want a decent payoff. A four power attacker is fine, but not when it will almost certainly die the first time it attacks. The payoff here, of a one-toughness creature, just isn't enough for a card with islandhome. As, say, a 3/3 it would probably have been playable.

2807: Giant Slug.author: Salient
2807: Giant Slug.text_parsed:
Historic. The very first unblockable creature.

The dual lands like Underground Sea counted (and still count) as basic land types, and back then there just weren't that many other nonbasic lands. If you weren't going mono-artifact, you were susceptible to one of the five landwalks.

Obviously ": This creature is unblockable until end of turn" is not aggressively costed, even for its day... until you remember that you were required to run Homelands cards in many tournament formats of that time. Giant Slug plus Feast of the Unicorn was a serious late-game finisher.

If you ever play some kind of Old Cards Pauper game, run the slugfeast beast with Wall of Shadows and Will-o'-the-Wisp, both of which are nasty with Feast of the Unicorn. You could employ Drudge Skeletons and Unholy Strength to round out the deck with a 'buffs + regeneration' theme.

Invisible Stalker is the latest in a long line of critters for whom Giant Slug was seminal. :)

2807: Giant Slug.author: Aquillion

There is one (very small) interesting thing about this card: It gains the ability on your next upkeep, which means that you can pump left-over mana into it at the end of your opponent's turn.

Obviously this doesn't matter because it has one power, but it's interesting design, and would have been fun in permission decks if it had been on a creature with higher power.

2809: Hell's Caretaker.author: Salient
2809: Hell's Caretaker.text_parsed:
Phenomenally enjoyable casual card. I had a lot of fun running this in my Karador, Ghost Chieftain deck. It's not an overpowered bomb, but it provides a surprising level of versatility and synergy with cards that have powerful ETB effects. A cantrip creature becomes a draw engine; a ramp/landfetch creature (Yavimaya Elder, Yavimaya Granger or Pilgrim's Eye) becomes brokenly repeatable. To fuel the combo

I've been running this with Bloodghast, Nether Traitor, etc, but you could use token generators instead. I could even see using this to bounce Snapcaster Mage to maintain a control presence in .

Damn oracle errata

2812: Recall.author: mtkaim
2812: Recall.text_parsed:
@shotoku64: You are wrong. With the old wording you also had the old rulings, which said that things worded "Do aaaa to do bbbb" mean that if aaaa is not done, bbbb is not done either. The keyword is the word to. If it were worded "Discard X cards and take X cards from your graveyard to your hand", then you could get cards with an empty hand to begin with, even with the old rulings.

It's funny how some people comment to old card texts without knowing the rulings of that time.
2812: Recall.text_posted:
@shotoku64: You are wrong. With the old wording you also had the old rulings, which said that things worded "Do aaaa to do bbbb" mean that if aaaa is not done, bbbb is not done either. The keyword is the word [b]to[/b]. If it were worded "Discard X cards and take X cards from your graveyard to your hand", then you could get cards with an empty hand to begin with, even with the old rulings.

It's funny how some people comment to old card texts without knowing the rulings of that time.

2821: Wall of Vapor.author: fissionessence
2821: Wall of Vapor.text_parsed:
Andrew's Occasional Random Card of the Day #8 - 7/4/2011 - Wall of Vapor

Compare to Darksteel Myr.

Well, Wall of Vapor is better against infect and wither creatures! Since they deal their damage in the form of -1/-1 counters, but damage to the Wall is prevented, it's safe. Darksteel Myr doesn't have that luxury. The Myr is a mana cheaper, though, and colorless.

Anyway, it's kind of silly to compare the power level of newer and older cards. Wall of Vapors, while I've never seen it played, I'm sure has nostalgia for some people. A local player in my casual playgroup had a deck built around walls, full of the glyphs. I don't know that he had this particular one, but it seems like it would have been a good fit, right down to the old card frame and Legends expansion symbol. Also, come on! This thing could block a Craw Wurm all day! That had to have counted for something.

If I really had to make a fuss about something with this card, it would be that its ability makes it feel 'indestructible', and not just by the current Magic usage of the term. A wall of vapor doesn't feel 'indestructible'; it feels intangible. "Protection from attacking creatures," has a certain ring to it. Or perhaps, "Whenever Wall of Vapor blocks a creature, that creature's power becomes 0 until end of turn." Each has its nuance, but I'd just be looking for a wording that makes it sound like a fluffy cloud more than an immovable object.

They need to revisit the text of this card. Both printings specify that the end benefit is that a creature gains flying (last indefinitely) and a +1/+1 counter. 2830: Emerald Dragonfly.author: The_Erudite_Idiot
2830: Emerald Dragonfly.text_parsed:
I usually don't engage in tactical rating, but for you Emerald Dragonfly, I give you a five.

Oozing with flavor/
Never seen in tournaments/
A casual treat!

I would put a couple of dragonflies in my deck and would claim that they were good luck. This card has all of the hallmarks of good design.

Ethics is not something confined to certain spheres of life, ethics applies to card design, and this is an ethical triumph. Whimsy should always have a place in our lives and in our decks. The one who builds a deck merely to win games can win a tournament, but she can never pluck the fruits hanging from the highest branches.

2831: Erhnam Djinn.author: tezcat
2831: Erhnam Djinn.text_parsed: I had great success with this guy during the Ice Age/Alliances and Mirage block era of Magic, playing an Erhnam-n-Burn'em deck. With Orcish Lumberjack or Tinder Wall, you could get him out on the second turn and commence the beat down. The deck also featured Jokulhaups, allowing ten mana to set you up with the only creature (and a beefy one, though Lhurgoyf would often be bigger in that scenario) in play, and your opponent nigh helpless to do anything but die within a few turns. Now try that one with Emperor Crocodile!

2832: Ghazbán Ogre.author: Palochka
2832: Ghazbán Ogre.text_parsed:
Braid_of_Fire's Card of the Day #5

A win-more card for the mono-green or 10-land stompy decks, and a difficult cut for my 450 cube.

The idea that you're ahead on life in a deck with 30+ one-drops and a bunch of Giant Growth effects is not unreasonable, but the moment that the game swings out of your favor, you lose. I'd much rather see this kind of effect in Black, which is less concerned about loyalty as Green is.

I really dislike how Chronicles retained the original set's set symbol. As the set that created such a controversy that WotC began the Reserved List, I can empathize with the way people were so offended. Though an overreaction on both the sides of the players and Wizards with unfortunate impact on the future of Magic, there was at least justification for the emotions surrounding the Reserved List's creation.

Back to the Ogre, I very much wish he were black, or that Planar Chaos had a black version. The same goes for his friend and brother Wild Dogs, who also narrowly misses out on inclusion in my 450 cube. I'd just rather have a Pouncing Jaguar or even a Scythe Tiger, even if this ogre has more fun art than the rest of the bunch.

2833: Metamorphosis.author: Keldane

This plus Worldspine Wurm has the potential to be a lot of fun. Bam! Eleven green mana with which to cast whatever you want, AND you still have three 5/5 tramplers. Better still is to do this in a Hero deck, with Worldspine Wurm as your Hero - Cast it one turn, sac it to Metamorphosis the following turn and for the cost of one tapped land, you can replay it immediately. Three 5/5 tramplers, and a nice, horrific 15/15.

Coincidentally, a Hero deck built around powering out Worldspine Wurm as fast as possible is the only one in which I've ever found use for Boundless Realms.

2841: Beasts of Bogardan.author: CAustin582
2841: Beasts of Bogardan.text_parsed:
Ok, so:

3/3 for 5 CMC... no stars there
Protection from red. Any 3/3 is much better off with protection from red. That's worth a solid star.
+1/+1 if an opponent has a white permanent? All that does is make it a conditional 4/4 for 5 CMC, which is still bad. This may be written down as a separate ability, but it's still negligible given the mana cost. 0 stars for that.

Total: 1 star
Hilariously enough, I would go so far as to say this card is rated over twice as high as it should be.

2844: Goblin Artisans.author: stygimoloch
2844: Goblin Artisans.text_parsed: The Oracle wording here is dodgy. Since the artifact-countering is listed as part of the effect rather than the cost, this becomes a one-drop, in a card-advantage-weak colour, which has a 50/50 chance of drawing you an extra card each turn, with effectively no drawback. That's pretty much changed one of the most mocked and useless creatures ever printed to a certifiable star.

That way it about evens out in the card advantage area.

2844: Goblin Artisans.author: AdenNeda
2844: Goblin Artisans.text_parsed:
I believe what stygimoloch is referring to is that the oracle text has removed the timing restrictions. It no longer requires an artifact spell to be on the stack when you activate the ability. Whether or not you can activate an ability without a target I do not know, but if so then the losing effect would have nothing to counter and would thus fizzle.

I agree with styg's thoughts on the card, though my opinion may be biased because I use this card in a deck along with Krark's Thumb and Chance Encounter, among others.

Yes, if you take the Oracle text word for word, you can activate the ability any time, because there's no line at the end saying, "You can only use this ability when your opponent casts an artifact spell."
So, if you go by the Oracle text, this card is a diamond in the rough, and a card that would definitely be used today.
If you go by the original, it's very lacking because it requires that your opponent plays an artifact for it to do anything.

2844: Goblin Artisans.author: Salient
2844: Goblin Artisans.text_parsed:
@AdenNeda and Weretarrasque : You can't activate an ability (or cast a spell) unless you are able to choose all appropriate targets for it. Without an artifact spell on the stack, Artisans' ability can't be activated. This confused me too for a while, but it's in the Comprehensive Rules, so they don't need to specify it. (It's basically the same rule that says "you can't cast Shatter targeting nothing to get it out of your hand" and etc. I can look up the rule number later, if I think of it.)

If there is an artifact spell on the stack targeted by Goblin Artisans, and for some weird reason the spell gets removed from the stack before Artisans' ability resolves -- maybe by Venser, Shaper Savant bouncing the artifact spell -- then the ability fizzles, because it did not have legal targets upon resolution.
2844: Goblin Artisans.text_posted:
@AdenNeda and Weretarrasque : You can't activate an ability (or cast a spell) unless you are able to choose all appropriate targets for it. Without an artifact spell on the stack, Artisans' ability can't be activated. This confused me too for a while, but it's in the Comprehensive Rules, so they don't need to specify it. (It's basically the same rule that says "you can't cast Shatter targeting nothing to get it out of your hand" and etc. I can look up the rule number later, if I think of it.)

If there is an artifact spell on the stack targeted by Goblin Artisans, and for some weird reason the spell gets removed from the stack before Artisans' ability resolves -- maybe by [autocard]Venser, Shaper Savant[/autocard] bouncing the artifact spell -- then the ability fizzles, because it did not have legal targets upon resolution.

2844: Goblin Artisans.author: EvilCheesecake
2844: Goblin Artisans.text_parsed:
SO MANY WRONG INTERPRETATIONS OF THIS CARD.

As a judge, here's what you need to know:

-There needs to be an artifact that you cast on the stack for this to target in order for you to be allowed to activate it. If that artifact spell is already a target of an Artisan, it's not a legal target.
-If you lose the flip, the artifact is countered. If you win the flip, you draw a card. Otherwise, your artifact is countered. Nothing else happens.
-If one Artisan's ability resolves and doesn't counter the spell, you can then put another Artisan's ability on the stack targeting the same spell.
-Krark's Thumb is indeed boss with this card, as is Karplusan Minotaur.
2844: Goblin Artisans.text_posted:

-If you lose the flip, the artifact is countered. If you win the flip, you draw a card. Otherwise, your artifact is countered. Nothing else happens.
-If one Artisan's ability resolves and doesn't counter the spell, you can then put another Artisan's ability on the stack targeting the same spell.
-Krark's Thumb is indeed boss with this card, as is Karplusan Minotaur.

2848: Land's Edge.author: blurrymadness
2848: Land's Edge.text_parsed:
turn every land into a near-shock for no mana? And they're free to "cast"? and "uncounterable"?

I've been trying this out more recently and it's fantastic to get a good 2-6 points of burn in at the end of the game. Great with Madness cards as well, but that feature is largely unnecessary to make it useful. Combo'd with Wheel of Fate/Fortune you'll fill up your hand AND dish out a ton of pain. Worth considering in any casual burn deck.

In a green/blue/red deck you can also pull the combo:
scouting trek
treasure hunt
land's edge

Turn 4 you're pumping 40ish damage in straight, near-uncounterable burn. THAT is insane. Turn 3 is easy with a Birds of Paradise and something like Sol Ring or Mana Vault.. etc.

T1 Forest, BoP
T2 Mountain, Tap Mountain for 1 Mana, Play Sol Ring or Mana Vault, Play Scouting trek, use BoP and remaining colorless for Treasure hunt
T3 tap Forest, Mountain, BoP, play Land's Edge, discard the lands in your hand for 2 damage a piece

Unfortunately it's still a pretty lucky hand and such, but doable by T3.

@champ-kitty
to be fair, this costs no mana and can't hurt your hand. Further, this is great in a land destruction deck because then your opponent doesn't really have the option to return the favor.

T2 Mountain, Tap Mountain for 1 Mana, Play [autocard]Sol Ring[/autocard] or [autocard]Mana Vault[/autocard], Play [autocard]Scouting trek[/autocard], use BoP and remaining colorless for [autocard]Treasure hunt[/autocard]
T3 tap Forest, Mountain, BoP, play [autocard]Land's Edge[/autocard], discard the lands in your hand for 2 damage a piece

Unfortunately it's still a pretty lucky hand and such, but doable by T3.

@champ-kitty
to be fair, this costs no mana and can't hurt your hand. Further, this is great in a land destruction deck because then your opponent doesn't really have the option to return the favor.

It'll probably attract some creature kill, but in order to do that they have to stop paying for it, now don't they? That makes it technically a two-for-one, but with the benefits of lightning bolt damage (at least, probably) and removing a kill spell specifically. And if they don't have one? Heh.

2867: Axelrod Gunnarson.author: DoctorKenneth
2867: Axelrod Gunnarson.text_parsed:
I think we're all forgetting the most important fact here: his name sounds like like he's the lead singer of an 80's hard rock band. Axelrod Gunnarson? He may as well be Axel Hotrod von Gunsandroses Grateful Dead.

Anyway, I really dislike the notion that big spells should win the game on their own. It is, of course, correct to assume that they DO, I just don't think it should be the case. Often, it's a matter of who can get their $20 card to stick first- and granted, the effects of which are often epic (far be it from me to say that smashing face with Akroma doesn't feel good)- but I don't think reaching eight mana should ever be game over. I mean, the meta is packed with enough removal to make the United States missile stockpile blush, but eight mana should mean a very, very good card, not instant death. I guess I'm just a sucker for long games.

I also want to make clear that I am not insane, and this card IS overcosted, despite my rant.

2868: Ayesha Tanaka.author: kitsunewarlock
2868: Ayesha Tanaka.text_parsed:
one of the earliest Artificer creatures in Magic. She was the armorer of Testuo Umezawa and has more backstory than one would expect from a card with no flavor text. Her picture isn't that noteworthy--the markings on her face are pretty neat, but the rather silly looking armor behind her takes up so much of the card that its hard to tell what Tanaka really looks like. I can't even tell if she has hair or clothes or not...It looks more appropriate for an instant or sorcery than a creature...especially if the creature is the person and not the armor. But she is an armorsmith so it makes sense. And the color sceme matches her colors.

Her casting cost is pretty difficult to hit, having 2 colored mana symbols with no colorless or hybrid to help alleviate the burden. Statistically she is only a 2/2. She isn't black, nor an artifact, has no shroud or regeneration...so she is quite difficult to keep alive. Name a form of removal and she is most likely susceptible to it. She has banding, which is really only nice in this case if your blocking (as you would probably never attack with her).

Her true strength lies in her ability. Being able to counter activated abilities as an activated ability is pretty sweet. And if your opponent isn't playing white, you can completely lock down their strongest artifacts. She can stop equipment from being equipped (although they can just equip again if they have enough mana) and she can cancel Sensei's Diving Top from hiding on the top of the library when you try to kill it with a Disenchant or the like.

Really it almost goes without saying that this card is *only* appropriate as side-board against artifact decks, or with cards like Memnarch. Unfortunately, Mytosynch Lattice causes her ability to weaken, as your opponent can then use any mana to pay her "unless" cost.

She really seems to shine in EDH. With so many staple artifacts in EDH (Tormod's Crypt, Mind Slaver, Engineered Explosives, Top...), she can really ruin someone's day. She's actually a damned good blue/white general too. Much better than Gwafa Hazeed, in my personal opinion.

2868: Ayesha Tanaka.author: A3Kitsune
2868: Ayesha Tanaka.text_parsed:
@kitsunewarlock:

She has hair - it may be hard to make out if your copy of this card doesn't have sharp colors, but it's blocking part of the armor. She also has clothes, or at least a top. Note the difference in coloration between her shoulder and the other visable parts of her. Also note the shine on said shoulder, and the pale yellow edging where shoulder meets neck.

It would have been nice if she had an ability that helped you find and/or put into play artifacts instead of banding. But, all in all, not bad.

2872: Johan.author: orisiti
2872: Johan.text_parsed:
giving him defender doesn't solve the problem, as creatures with defender can still attack under certain circumstances, and it still doesn't address the "tapped" clause.

I like how the people who write the rules text for oracle spend their days contemplating the rules text to get it to work exactly the way it was intended, and then every one gets on here and presumes they could have done better... and there are so many combos and tricky plays that require small differences in the rulings, i don't think it so much of a stretch that someone would try to use him that way.

also, it can't be an activated ability, those are more easily countered/prevented than triggered abilities such as his are.

2872: Johan.author: tpkatsa
2872: Johan.text_parsed:
I asked my 9 year old which is easier to understand...the card text or the oracle text. She said, "well obviously the card text, Dad."

Having said this, they could have written, "If Johan is untapped, you may have creatures you control gain vigilance until end of turn. If you do, Johan cannot attack this turn."

I'm not a magic lawyer but I t1hink this wording is much easier to understand than the oracle text. This also passed the kid test. :)

As to the card itself, it's not a bad card, but in most cases I'd rather simply run a Serra's Blessing. Maybe useful in a Naya deck or Legends deck. 5/4 that effectively gives vigilance is not that bad. Would be better at 5 cmc. But Johan was good when we played back in the days of Legends.

2872: Johan.author: Salient
2872: Johan.text_parsed:
tpkatsa, I've never understood why people are upset when the printed card text is easier to understand than the Oracle text. While you're playing Magic, you only see one of the two; isn't it better when the text you see every game is the text that's easier to understand?

Oracle is meant to address all possible rules concerns, etc, so it's going to be somewhat lawyerly. I actually came here to look up rulings and was surprised to find there aren't any.

2881: Stangg.author: vantha
2881: Stangg.text_parsed:
Legends is a weird set. In some ways they wanted to demonstrate the raw power of being a legend creature type for Magic. But the irony, being most of the Legends coming out of Legends were so bad they actually demonstrated the Raw weakness of the Legend type.

Costing and being a Legend in today's environment gets you a Ruric Thar, the Unbowed compare the 2 creatures and you will see what I mean. Given that whoever plays their creature first will be forced to attack. But Ruric Thar turns the tide of the game completely, while Stang just makes a copy of himself. Add the fact that Stang has a serious drawback of sorrow issues.

Stang would've been perfect if him and his twin had haste. 6 damage on Turn 6 is really good, combined with a 3/4 body that would most likely survive combat.

2882: Tobias Andrion.author: Aquillion
2882: Tobias Andrion.text_parsed:
For people who are confused by its high casting cost, I can explain.

Legends was the first set to have Legends or multicolored cards. The idea back then was that they would represent heroes who would work together in parties; to support this, they included a cycle of cards like Adventurers' Guildhouse and Cathedral of Serra. They thought that those bands-with-others cards were really powerful, and that being a multicolored legend (especially a big one) was therefore an advantage.

At the time, large banding creatures were considered hugely powerful (they're pretty powerful, really, but few people actually used banding.) Of course the Adventurer's Guildhouse and friends were still terrible-- they were far too limited in scope, they took up an important land drop, and while big banding creatures are nice, they're not nice enough to be worth devoting an entire extra card to granting banding, especially in such a limited form. So those cards were immediately forgotten, and we're left with a bunch of overpriced multi-colored legends meant for use with a mechanic that didn't gel.

(There were a few good legends in Legends, but mostly they were the tri-color ones -- they did recognize that three colors was a drawback, so some of them, like Tetsuo Umezawa and Angus Mackenzie, got nifty abilities.)

2882: Tobias Andrion.author: SeriouslyFacetious
2882: Tobias Andrion.text_parsed:
So I actually played during the time that Chronicles was a new set. Because I was 11 and terrible at the game I bought quite a few Chronicles boosters...

One time I was trading cards with an equally young friend -- for some reason he was interested in my Chronicles version of Tobias Andrion. Once the exchange was made, I jokingly said "listen man, trade backs". Because we usually said "no trade backs".

My friend took one look at the card and took me up on the offer. Being an 11 year old all he saw was the gold border and the type line "Summon Legend"... But I guess even a little kid playing MtG in 1996 expects more than flavour text for {3}{W}{U}.

Homework assignment: Compare and contrast this card with Geist of Saint Traft. Min 2500 words. Bonus points for not using the word "zeitgeist". Triggering Godwin's Law = instant fail.

2895: Urza's Power Plant.author: KokoshoForPresident
2895: Urza's Power Plant.text_parsed: Why doesn't Urza get a planeswalker card?  I'll bet it's because they can't think of any way to make it powerful enough without being broken.

2895: Urza's Power Plant.author: Wurmcaller
2895: Urza's Power Plant.text_parsed:
Actually, Kokosho, it's because Urza is dead. He's been dead a while now too. He died to defeat Yawgmoth, his arch-nemesis, creator and god of the plane of Phyrexia.

He died long before the nature of the Planeswalker spark was changed in Time Spiral, giving us the Planeswalkers as we know them today. Before Time Spiral, Planeswalkers were more akin to demi-gods than to just powerful mages with the ability to walk across planes of reality.

2898: Urza's Tower.text_parsed:
"Okay, Urza, what do you need funding for today?"
"You know that wide plains to the east?"
"Oh, the uninhabitable landscape with the scorching sun and the icy, frigid nights, with ancient burial grounds abound?"
"Yeah, I'm building a tower there."
"...You know, anybody else, and they wouldn't get more than a scoff."
"That's why you're the best. Of course, I could always stop sending you ornithopters."
"...Here's your funding."
